Tyler Close wrote:
> On Wednesday 02 July 2003 10:52, Mark Baker wrote:
> ...
> 
> It is not the URI on its own that I am arguing against. It is the
> absence of the user-specific resource URI that I am arguing
> against. I am arguing against using HTTP Auth as a resource
> identification supplement. The example URL is an example of a URL
> that requires supplemental resource identification information in
> order to provide any function.
> 
> An application may very well provide container URLs, in addition
> to user-specific URLs, and be RESTful. It is the absence of the
> user-specific URLs that is RESTless.

Trying to decide how many resources there are behind a URL is kind of an 
angels-on-the-head-of-a-pin question. But it is demonstrably necessary 
to make URLs to things that behave differently for different people 
(whether different because of conneg, or language sniffing, or HTTP 
version or username/password or ...)

 From a UI point of view it is important to be clear with the user about 
what the resource is.

But we're somewhat far afield of what the user asked. Can the system 
deny access to other people's cities? The answer is clearly that REST 
allows this. Tyler's favorite security model may not, but REST has no 
problem with it. The issue of whether the user sees their own cities at 
a user-specific URL or user-generic URL is separate.

  Paul Prescod
